abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            improving health services to reduce child and maternal
            mortality in Djibouti. Djibouti’s health indicators remained
            among the lowest in the world. Both the infant mortality
            rate and maternal mortality rate were among the highest in
            the region. The Tuberculosis rate was among the highest in
            the world. Malaria was also on the rise, with over 4,000
            confirmed cases each year. In terms of capacity, the sector
            was in dire need of strengthening its health service
            delivery system and management capacity in order to achieve
            the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). The Bank has been
            the leading donor in the health sector through two major
            projects, Health Sector Development Project and the HIV,
            AIDS, Malaria and Tuberculosis Control Project. Working with
            the World Bank, Djibouti had brought down the child
            mortality rate, while HIV and AIDS prevalence among young
            pregnant women decreased to 2 percent in 2009. Djibouti has
            made significant progress in improving its health services.
